questions.text: All of the following are true about NLPHL (Nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma) Except:

options.label: D
options.text: Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.correct_answer: D. Poor prognosis compared to classical HL
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Poor prognosis compared to classical HL Hodgkin lymphoma Nodular lymphocyte predominant Approximately 5 -10% of all Hodgkin lymphoma cases. Annual incidence of approximately 1/830, 000. M:F = 3:1; median age at presentation 30 - 40 years. Sites: Peripheral lymph nodes generally – cervical, axillary, inguinal. Mesenteric lymph nodes can be affected. Mediastinal involvement is rare. Clinical features Usually presents as localized disease; usually stage I / II (70 - 80%); 20% may present with advanced stage disease. Advanced stage disease treated as an aggressive B cell lymphoma. Presents with peripheral lymphadenopathy; rarely mediastinal or bone marrow involvement; often long history of localized disease · M > F. Wide age range; may present in children. B symptoms are uncommon (5 - 10%). Late recurrences more common than in classic Hodgkin lymphoma. Diagnosis Biopsy of the involved lymph node with immunohistochemistry. LP cells in a background of small lymphocytes admixed with histiocytes. LP cells: CD45+, CD20+, PAX5+ OCT+, BCL6+, CD15-, CD30 variable (Mostly negative); Subset positive for IgD, mainly in young males. Background: small B cells and T cells positive for CD4, PD-1 and partial CD57. Prognostic factors Excellent prognosis; remission rate of 90 - 100% after primary therapy and overall 10 year survival rates > 90% in limited stage disease.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in given Peripheral smear?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B12 deficiency Most often hypersegmented neutrophils are associated with megaloblastic anemia and are said to be pathognomonic of the disease. Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by folic acid deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency (including pernicious anemia). Hypersegmentation of neutrophils may also be seen in myelodysplastic syndromes, when receiving chemotherapy, or in long-term chronic infections. The cells seen in these conditions would be classified as pathological since the body is responding abnormally as a result of either a deficiency of a component needed for DNA production or because of the toxic effect that chemotherapy drugs have on DNA A hypersegmented neutrophil showing seven segments is present in this Image .

questions.text: A patient with weight gain and lassitude. Investigations show increased TSH with low T4, What is your clinical impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis The given clinical scenario with history of weight gain and lassitude , along with the laboratory findings of increased TSH and low T4 suggests the diagnosis of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism.

Highyeild:

Hashimoto thyroiditis Aka chronic autoimmune thyroiditis A most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions. Associated with HLA-DR3 Increased risk of primary thyroid lymphoma- diffuse large B-cell lymphoma Features: Moderately enlarged, non-tender thyroid May be preceded by transient hyperthyroid state: Hashitoxicosis due to follicular rupture Serology: Antithyroid peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies present Histology: Hurthle cells , lymphoid aggregates with germinal centres Treatment: Toxic phase: Beta-blocker Hypothyroid state: T4 supplements

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Grave's disease:It is an autoimmune disorder that leads to hyperthyroidism, characterized by excessive production of thyroid hormones.The laboratory findings in Grave's disease would show decreased TSH levels and increased T4 levels, as opposed to the increased TSH and low T4 levels seen in the patient's investigations. Option C. Pituitary adenoma: These are tumors that develop in the pituitary gland and can cause hormonal imbalances. Pituitary adenomas can cause hormonal disturbances, but they typically affect multiple hormones produced by the pituitary gland, not solely the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). Option D. Hypoparathyroidism: It is a condition characterized by decreased parathyroid hormone (PTH) production, which leads to low calcium levels and increased phosphorus levels in the blood.Hypoparathyroidism is unrelated to thyroid hormone production.

Without functional parietal cells, intrinsic factor production is reduced, resulting in impaired vitamin B12 absorption and subsequent anemia. Option B . Carcinoid syndrome:It is caused by neuroendocrine tumors, known as carcinoids, that produce and release hormones, including serotonin, into the bloodstream. This results in various symptoms such as flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and other systemic manifestations. Option D. Vitamin B12 deficiency: It can occur due to various reasons, including impaired absorption. Parietal cells in the stomach produce the intrinsic factor, which is required for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the small intestine. questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with easy fatigability and pallor. The Image from her hand is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B12 deficiency Knuckle pigmentation is seen in the setting of vitamin B12 deficiency. In vitamin B12 deficiency, there is an increased production of oxidants like homocysteine. This leads to relative glutathione depletion leading to the activation of the tyrosinase enzyme. This results in the increased synthesis of melanin leading to pigmentation particularly at knuckles and oral mucosa. Folic acid deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia associated with neurological symptoms. Fe deficiency results in hypochromic microcytic anemia with the hair, skin (pallor), and nail changes (koilonychia). Vitamin B6 deficiency also leads to anemia which is not responsive to the vitamin B12, folic acid, or iron supplementation as it is requires as a coenzyme for the ALA synthase enzyme of heme synthesis.

questions.text: Target cells are formed due to excess of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cell membrane Target cells, or Codocytes, appear in conditions that cause the surface of the red cell to increase disproportionately to its volume. This may result from a decrease in hemoglobin, as in iron deficiency anemia, or an increase in cell membrane. Macrocytic target cells can be seen in liver disease, and microcytic target cells may be seen in thalassemia.

questions.text: JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polycythemia vera The JAK2 V617F mutation is an acquired, somatic mutation present in the majority of patients with myeloproliferative cancer (myeloproliferative neoplasms) i.e. nearly 100% of patients with polycythemia vera and in about 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis and primary myelofibrosis. The JAK2 V617F mutation may also be prevalent in individuals without overt signs of myeloproliferative cancer. However, the significance of the mutation in this setting is unknown, leading us to examine whether presence of the JAK2 V617F mutation in individuals from the general population is associated with poor health.

questions.text: A child was brought to the ER with a lesion on the forearm as seen. As a surgery resident, you decide to excise the lesion in emergency OT. Which of the following investigation will test for the entire coagulation pathway:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thromboelastography Thromboelastography (TEG) is a viscoelastic hemostatic assay that measures the global viscoelastic properties of whole blood clot formation under low shear stress. TEG shows the interaction of platelets with the coagulation cascade (aggregation, clot strengthening, fibrin cross-linking and fibrinolysis) The PT test evaluates how well all of the coagulation factors { I (Fibrinogen), II (Prothrombin), V, VII and X } in the extrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade work together. aPTT, evaluates the clotting factors that are part of the intrinsic and common pathways: XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and I (fibrinogen) as well as Pre-kallikrein (PK) and high molecular weight kininogen (HK). Interpretation of TEG tracing TEG parameter Correlations with phase of coagulation Reaction time (min) Time between initiation of coagulation cascade to initial formation of fibrin Kinetic time (min) Time between initial formation of fibrin to specific clot firmness (20 mm) a-angle (degrees) Rate of fibrin formation and crosslinking Maximum amplitude (mm) Maximum clot strength Lysis-30 (%) Fibrinolysis 30 minutes after maximum amplitude

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will have the least chances of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Follicular lymphoma The diagnosis and management of many haematological diseases depends on examination of the bone marrow, which involves two separate specimens i.e. a cytologic and a histologic preparation. Failure to obtain bone marrow on attempted marrow aspiration, "dry tap," has commonly been ascribed to significant marrow pathology, usually associated with fibrosis, or hypercellularity, or both. These conditions most likely account for the inability to aspirate marrow. The most frequent diagnoses are: Metastatic carcinoma, Acute (especially AML-M7) and chronic myelogenous leukemia, Idiopathic myelofibrosis, Secondary myelofibrosis MDS (Myelodysplastic Syndrome) Hairy cell leukemia. The presence of peripheral blood nucleated red blood cells, thrombocytopenia, and elevation of the serum lactate dehydrogenase were frequent findings in patients who experienced dry taps.

questions.text: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is associated with: HIV SLE CLL Hepatitis B Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, 4 Membrano-proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a form of glomerulonephritis caused by an abnormal immune response. Deposits of antibodies build up in glomerular basement membrane which helps filter wastes and extra fluids from the blood. Damage to basement membrane affects the kidney's ability to create urine normally, which in turn causes blood and protein to leak into the urine. The 2 forms of this disease are MPGN I and MPGN II. Most people with the disease have type I. MPGN II is much less common. It also tends to get worse faster than MPGN I. Causes of MPGN include: Autoimmune diseases (systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, Sjögren syndrome, sarcoidosis). Cancer (Leukaemia, lymphoma). Infections (HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Endocarditis, Malaria).

questions.text: What fixation technique is used for fat in HPE?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Frozen section It is quite difficult to visualize the lipids in histology because they are dissolved in the solvents used for the preparation of the tissues. This means that the lipids can disappear from the tissue during the preparation and especially when it comes to paraffin sections. It is for this reason that Frozen sections are more commonly used for lipid visualization. However, not all lipids are eliminated by solvents. This is the case of lipids that bind to other molecules such as lipoproteins, lipofuscins and myelin. On the contrary, triglycerides are always removed by the solvents during the preparation of paraffin tissues. The cell membranes are composed of a large amount of lipoproteins, and although these are not dissolved by the solvents, it is very difficult to demonstrate them by conventional methods of lipid staining. IHC: Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is the most common application of immuno staining. It involves the process of selectively identifying antigens (proteins) in cells of a tissue section by exploiting the principle of antibodies binding specifically to antigens in biological tissues. Frozen section: Fat tissue A frozen section (cryo section) is a pathological laboratory technique used for rapid microscopic analysis / diagnosis of a specimen / disease Usually used with oncologic surgery Rapid diagnosis can guide intra-operative patient management
